Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports the participation of graduate students, postdocs, and other early-career mathematicians in the Twenty-Third Riviere-Fabes Symposium, held at the University of Minnesota on April 24-26, 2020. The award gives junior researchers, researchers who are members of underrepresented groups, and researchers without other sources of funding a chance to attend and participate in this conference, thus helping to promote the future generation of scientists working in mathematical analysis.

The symposium focuses on recent developments in the field of analysis, with this year's program having a particular focus on the analysis of partial differential equations (Navier-Stokes, Schroedinger, elliptic, dispersive, porous media equations, optimal regularity). More information can be found on the symposium web page: https://math.umn.edu/riviere-fabes-symposium/riviere-fabes-2020

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Institution.Name: University of Minnesota-Twin Cities
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award sponsored the participation of young researchers in the annual Riviere-Fabes symposium in Analysis and PDE held at the University of Minnesota: a unique conference which comibines both scientific and educational components. Each year four prominent speakers from various branches of analysis and partial differential equations are invited to present two lectures each specifically tailored towards early career mathematicians. Thus young mathematicians are presented with an opportunity to learn cutting edge topics in analysis and PDE from the top experts in the field, helping educate and develop the next generation of analysts. Almost all US experts in analysis and PDE have at some poitn of their careers have attended this annual event.

Funds in this project were initially requested for the 2020 symposium, which has been unfortunately cancelled due to the pandemic; the next symposium was held in 2021 online, but finally in 2022 the symposium happenned in person with  four outstanding speakers : Henri Berestycki (online),   Yaiza Canzani,   Juhi Jang, Charles Smart. A small portion of the funds was also used to support participants of the 2023 symposium (28 participants in 2022, and 6 in 2023). The 2023 symposium featured an equally excellent list of lecturers: Xiumin Du,  Thomas Hou, Danylo Radchenko, Jérémie Szeftel.

The list of topics covered in the 2022 and 2023 lectures touched upon many contemporary areas of analysis, partial differential equations, and adjacent fields, such as fluid dynamics, geometric measure theory, sphere packings, disctance geometry, homogenization, predator-prey models, Weyl laws and many other modern and relevant topics, creating an excellent educational and scientific event.


Last Modified: 11/17/2024
Modified by: Dmitriy Bilyk
